Award.AwardTitle: Evaluating the Variables that Drive and Sustain Human Conflict in Agrarian Contexts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Civil wars have taken place in 73 countries since World War II, costing an estimated 16 million lives. As scholars attempt to establish generalizable patterns for the drivers and sustainers of conflict, and the conditions that are necessary for conflict resolution, the reliability of many scientific studies has been nagged by a noticeable lack of pre-conflict and post-conflict data for the specific contexts that they study. This project has the unusual advantage of being able to draw on a longitudinal data set, because of the researcher's long history of engagement with the research site and local scientific collaborators. By focusing on a range of decision-making processes in contexts long turned to as models for studies of conflict, the research aims to answer questions about what variables drive and sustain human conflict.

Dr. Mariane Ferme of the University of California, Berkeley, will collaborate with scholars based at Njala University, Sierra Leone (West Africa) to understand agrarian change in a number of "benchmark" rural contexts in that country, which have been the focus of prior research, or will be established as new sites for long-term study. While scholars agree that economic factors have at least some role in sustaining conflict, there is no widespread agreement on what drives it. The project seeks to answer this question by focusing on the decision-making processes involved in access to land and labor, property rights, and resource allocation through social institutions such as lineages, extended households, local political authorities and the courts, particularly in areas affected by large land deals with foreign investors. Sierra Leone is regarded as an important testing ground for theories about the drivers and sustainers of conflict, as its civil war represented a prima facie example of "extraversion", where a regime draws on external commercial and/or donor relationships rather than local taxation to maintain its political authority. Dr. Ferme's research focuses on three sites where she will conduct surveys, participant observation, and interviews, with an emphasis on access to justice, in areas where local grievances shaped the violence of the 1991-2002 civil war in Sierra Leone. This research will contribute to advance several bodies of social scientific knowledge: 1) on the drivers and sustainers of civil wars; 2) on agrarian change approached through novel interdisciplinary collaborations including archaeologists, geographers, experimental economists, and political scientists, in addition to cultural anthropologists, which offer insights over different temporal scales; and, 3) on the issue of so-called "land grabs" in Africa and elsewhere--large scale land deals, usually involving governments and business corporations, which displace small-holder, local farmers. Dr. Ferme also plans to study the impact of the legal empowerment movement, which in Sierra Leone places trained paralegals in rural chiefdoms to increase access to justice for the poor. Beyond its scholarly impact, this project promises to increase understanding of the social and intergenerational fragilities left in place in the aftermath of civil war, to shed light on the impact of new land policies which are rapidly changing the agrarian landscape, and to contribute to the training of a younger generation of Sierra Leonean social scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research aimed at shedding light on the phenomenon of "land grabs"--which, though happening on a global scale in the developing world, is disproportionately affecting the African continent--in Sierra Leone, West Africa. This small country emerged from civil war in 2002, and the decade following this conflict saw the development of policies aimed at facilitating entrepreneurial collaborations between subsistence farming communities and foreign direct investors interested in establishing largescale agricultural projects that can provide surpluses, and therefore stimulate production in a sector increasingly unable to feed a growing population concentrated in urban and peri-urban areas. At the same time, the lack of robust implementation measures for policies intended in theory to empower local farming communities has in some cases weakened land rights, and strengthened the hold of autocratic chiefs over their subjects, thus raising the specter of future conflicts over access to land for subsistence purposes.

            The project was funded before the 2014-16 Ebola Viral Disease (EVD) outbreak that spread across Sierra Leone and its two neighboring countries, Guinea and Liberia, and the research timetable (with sabbatical leaves already secured) overlapped significantly with this epidemic. This raised challenges to travel and research, but also underscored the vulnerability of post-conflict societies to disease outbreaks in countries where warfare resulted in weakened public health infrastructure, and in the outmigration of qualified medical personnel. The PI was able to collaborate with Sierra Leonean colleagues during times when foreign travel to the EVD-affected countries was virtually impossible, but also had an opportunity to observe firsthand the aftermath of the outbreak on agrarian communities. During periods of enforced shutdown of schools and universities, students from Njala University College were employed to assist in the research. But efforts to examine the consequences of two major land deals involving respectively largescale oil palm production (at the site of the company Socfin, in Pujehun District, Southern Province), and of sugarcane for ethanol production (Addax Bioenergy project, in Bombali District, Northern Province) were undermined by the fact that the EVD outbreak resulted in closure of facilities and the departure of virtually all the expatriate project leaderships. The economic crisis engendered by the EVD epidemic and other economic problems resulted in the shutdown of operations at Addax and a search for a buyer of its Sierra Leone project, and in the scaling back of Socfin's activities, reduced to milling services for local oil palm growers. The deficits incurred by these companies in the face of the EVD crisis made their future in Sierra Leone uncertain, let alone their willingness to engage in ethical, cooperative activities with the farming communities whose lands they lease.

            Notwithstanding these challenges, the PI was able to investigate the work done by "legal empowerment" NGOs (particularly Namati and Timap for Justice) in the arenas of land rights and in vetting contracts resulting from the call for "foreign direct investment" by the government of Sierra Leone, to ensure that rural communities are appropriately compensated for the lease of their land and the loss of valuable fruit, cocoa, coffee, and palm trees, and are given priority in hiring by these projects. Given the uncertainties of the post-Ebola economy, agrarian livelihoods in Sierra Leone appeared once again to be moving more towards dependency on subsistence farming than on largescale agricultural projects.
